articles.headline: Trump Pressures Obama Over U.N. Resolution on Israeli Settlements
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump’s forceful insertion into the matter reflected an unusual public split between incoming and outgoing presidents and underscored the stark shift on Middle East policy ahead.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump’s forceful insertion into the matter reflected an unusual public split between incoming and outgoing presidents and underscored the stark shift on Middle East policy ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — President-elect Donald J. Trump thrust himself into one of the world’s most polarizing debates on Thursday by pressuring President Obama to veto a United Nations resolution critical of Israel, the newly elected leader’s most direct intervention in foreign policy during his transition to power.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Somini Sengupta

articles.headline: Hedge Fund Math: Heads We Win, Tails You Lose
articles.snippet: Investors complain that Pershing Square Holdings kept approximately 72 percent of the fund’s gains for itself, leaving them with the remains.
articles.abstract: Investors complain that Pershing Square Holdings kept approximately 72 percent of the fund’s gains for itself, leaving them with the remains.
articles.lead_paragraph: When do 1.5 and 16 add up to 72?

articles.headline: Trump Says the U.S. Should Expand Its Nuclear Capacity
articles.snippet: A Twitter post from the president-elect appeared to suggest an end to decades of bipartisan efforts to limit nuclear weapons.
articles.abstract: A Twitter post from the president-elect appeared to suggest an end to decades of bipartisan efforts to limit nuclear weapons.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — President-elect Donald J. Trump said on Thursday that the United States should greatly “expand its nuclear capability,” appearing to suggest an end to decades of efforts by presidents of both parties to reduce the role of nuclear weapons in American defenses and strategy.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and James Glanz

articles.headline: Apple and Nokia Battle Over Cellphone Patents
articles.snippet: While companies like Apple now dominate smartphones, an earlier generation of phone makers like Nokia developed some of the technology.
articles.abstract: While companies like Apple now dominate smartphones, an earlier generation of phone makers like Nokia developed some of the technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple’s iPhone is a technological marvel. You can watch streaming video on it, download apps, take photos with its camera and give voice commands to Siri, its digital assistant. You can even make old-fashioned voice calls on it.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Mark Scott

articles.headline: Ordered Deported, Berlin Suspect Slipped Through Germany’s Fingers
articles.snippet: The case of Anis Amri, the suspect in Monday’s attack on a Christmas market, underscores a vexing problem: how to handle masses of virtually stateless wanderers.
articles.abstract: The case of Anis Amri, the suspect in Monday’s attack on a Christmas market, underscores a vexing problem: how to handle masses of virtually stateless wanderers.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — He left Tunisia, his family said, with dreams of making money and buying a car. After arriving in Italy, he was a violent inmate who spent time in six jails. In Germany, he was one of some 550 people identified as dangers to the state and placed under special surveillance.
articles.byline: By Alison Smale, Carlotta Gall and Gaia Pianigiani

articles.headline: 1MDB Case Hangs Over Goldman Sachs as Investigators Dig for Answers
articles.snippet: The firm says it thought the billions of dollars it raised for a Malaysian fund were used to buy legitimate assets, though prosecutors said they landed in personal accounts.
articles.abstract: The firm says it thought the billions of dollars it raised for a Malaysian fund were used to buy legitimate assets, though prosecutors said they landed in personal accounts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as Goldman Sachs is gaining a more prominent profile in the administration of Donald J. Trump, the Wall Street investment firm is undergoing scrutiny in an investigation in a sprawling international money laundering and embezzlement scheme.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Deutsche Bank to Settle Mortgage Inquiry for $7.2 Billion
articles.snippet: After months of talks, the bank is in a tentative deal to pay a $3.1 billion penalty and provide loan modifications worth $4.1 billion to American homeowners.
articles.abstract: After months of talks, the bank is in a tentative deal to pay a $3.1 billion penalty and provide loan modifications worth $4.1 billion to American homeowners.
articles.lead_paragraph: Deutsche Bank announced late on Thursday that it had reached a tentative $7.2 billion deal to resolve a federal investigation into its sale of toxic mortgage securities, capping months of negotiations that weighed heavily on the bank’s stock price and reputation.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: Hunt for Berlin Suspect Ends in Gunfire on an Italian Plaza
articles.snippet: Anis Amri, the 24-year-old Tunisian sought in connection with the rampage that killed 12 people at a Christmas market in Berlin, was killed by Italian police officers.
articles.abstract: Anis Amri, the 24-year-old Tunisian sought in connection with the rampage that killed 12 people at a Christmas market in Berlin, was killed by Italian police officers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SESTO SAN GIOVANNI, Italy — It was a routine identity check, the kind Italy has relied on to stem the flow of illegal migration deeper into Europe. But the man stopped by two police officers around 3 a.m. Friday outside the northern city of Milan was anything but an ordinary drifter.
articles.byline: By Elisabetta Povoledo, Gaia Pianigiani and Rukmini Callimachi

articles.headline: United Way Searches for Its Place in a World of One-Click Giving
articles.snippet: An increasing number of donors are asking whether they need a charitable middleman when causes and data galore are at their fingertips.
articles.abstract: An increasing number of donors are asking whether they need a charitable middleman when causes and data galore are at their fingertips.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since 1991, when The Chronicle of Philanthropy started publishing its annual list of the United States nonprofits that raise the most money from private sources, United Way has topped the list every year except for two.

articles.headline: Trump Says U.S. Would ‘Outmatch’ Rivals in a New Nuclear Arms Race
articles.snippet: President-elect Trump told MSNBC that if a new arms race occurred, “We will outmatch them at every pass and outlast them all.”
articles.abstract: President-elect Trump told MSNBC that if a new arms race occurred, “We will outmatch them at every pass and outlast them all.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — President-elect Donald J. Trump on Friday intensified his threat to “expand” America’s nuclear arsenal, saying he was willing to restart a nuclear arms race even as he released a letter from President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia that pointed toward the possibility of a “pragmatic” set of understandings between Washington and Moscow.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and David E. Sanger
